titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Lawrence Gilman Papers
titlestmt.author: by Molly Wheeler

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 05:10

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The papers consist of letters to Lawrence Gilman from various writers, poets, editors, and musicians, including Winifred Welles, Carl Van Vechten, Winston Churchill, John Farrar, Otto Klemperer, Marian MacDowell, H. L. Mencken, Ezra Pound, Bruno Walter, John Butler Yeats, and William Butler Yeats. A small amount of letters are from Gilman family members and an unidentified correspondent. Other papers include a draft of Gilman's "Bach the Great Modern," two notebooks, and clippings.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection includes materials previously identified by the following call numbers: Za Gilman, Uncat ZA File 42 and Uncat Za File 47.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Lawrence Gilman Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Lawrence Gilman Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

bioghist.head: Lawrence Gilman
bioghist.p: Lawrence Gilman, American author and music critic, was born on July 5, 1878 in Flushing, New York to Arthur Coit Gilman and Bessie Lawrence Gilman. His great uncle was the educator Daniel Coit Gilman. He studied at Collins Street Classical School in Hartford, CT, where he exhibited great talent for music theory and proficiency with several instruments. He worked for the New York Herald from 1896 to 1898 and as a music critic for Harper's Weekly , where he advanced to the position of managing editor, which he held from 1901 to 1913. Gilman worked as a general arts critic for the North American Review from 1915 to 1923, and for the Herald Tribune from 1925. On August 1, 1904, he married Elizabeth Wright Walter, with whom he had one child, Elizabeth "Betty" Lawrence Gilman in 1905. Gilman died on September 8, 1939 in Sugar Hill, New Hampshire.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters to Lawrence Gilman from various writers, poets, editors, artists, and musicians, including Winifred Welles, Carl Van Vechten, Winston Churchill, John Farrar, Otto Klemperer, Marian MacDowell, H. L. Mencken, Ezra Pound, Bruno Walter, John Butler Yeats, and William Butler Yeats. A small amount of letters are from Gilman family members and an unidentified correspondent. Other papers include a draft of Gilman's "Bach the Great Modern," two notebooks, and clippings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: I. Correspondence, 1886-1953. II. Writings and Other Papers, 1921-1971.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes draft of poem, "From a Kitten to Her Mistress"

scopecontent.p: On behalf of Little, Brown & Company

scopecontent.p: Includes drafts and clippings of poems by Hastings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photocopies of original letters. Includes 1972 letters from Elizabeth Anderson to Yale regarding the photocopies

did.unittitle: Correspondence with Lawrence and Elizabeth Gilman, photograph of Bessie Amelia Lawrence Gilman, and the pamphlet "An Analysis of the Drama of the Bibelung's Ring" by Julia S. Gilman
